results.notes:
Pileus: effused-reflexed, shelves up to 3cm wide and up to 14.5cm long, surface unevenly tomentose, a dark 7F7 to 6E6 where more bare, contour with somewhat rounded bumps where hairs are concentrated, margin naked or only with lighter, finer hairs.

Hymenium: poroid, 2-3 pores/ per mm, somewhat angular to rounded to circular at margin, 6C2 when fresh to 6F3-6D3 or darker in age, bruising 7F6 immediately (to 6C6 upon drying); tubes up to 1cm long, dissepiments thickest near margin, soon thinning; context ~3mm thick, 5C6 to 5E5, blackening instantly in KOH (drying to 9F5).

Odor/Taste: smells fragrant, like bread dough and sweet pencils, taste mild

Substrate: fallen, well-decorticated log

Habitat: landscaped/cultivated area, ~3400m

Ecoregion: Central Andean Wet Puna (NT1003)

Collector(s): D. Newman

Collection #: DSN12.014
results.location_name: Botanical Garden, Herbario Nacional de Bolivia, Universidad Mayor de San Andrés, Cota Cota, La Paz, Pedro Domingo Murillo Province, La Paz Department, Bolivia

results.notes:
same as Observation 273047

Pileus: ~3-2.5cm in diam, broadly conical when young to convex-conical, soon waxy, retailing umbo throughout; radially fibrillose, fibrils more concentrated at disc, fraying to reveal background toward margin; margin strongly incurved when young, slightly so in age; uniformly 5F5 when young, margin soon lightening (6E6 to 5D6 to 5B4), disc remaining darker than margin (5E8); background a light 5B2 to creamy white; texture smooth, cartilaginous, fragile, breaking easily; context white, unchanging in KOH.

Lamellae: broadly attached at all stages, ocassionally with a small decurrent tooth, creamy when young to 5B2 to 5B3; 5mm broad, subdistant to close; lamellulae present in one series

Stipe: up to 7.5cm long, 3-11mm thick, slightly enlarged above, twisted fibrous, cartilaginous, lighter above (6A2) to 6E6 to 6D7 below, shiny to pearlescent; context fibrous, roughly concolorous with pileus context, unchanging in KOH, pearlescent.

Partial Veil: cottony fibrillose to cortinoid, white, soon disappearing, flared upward on very young specimens, occasionally leaving an evanescent fibrillose zone on upper third of stipe.

Spore Deposit: not specifically recorded, presumed medium brown

Odor/Taste: faintly spermatic, taste mild

Substrate: in grass beneath Salix sp. (?)

Habitat: landscaped/cultivated area, ~3400m

Ecoregion: Central Andean Wet Puna (NT1003)

Collector(s): D. Newman

Collection #: DSN12.015

results.notes:
Pileus: up to 13mm in diam, varying degrees of centrally depressed, attached laterally, glabrous, surface ridged with the pore pattern, 6F5 to 5C4, lighter at center; texture rubbery-gelatinous; context white, unchanging in KOH.

Hymenium: poroid, ~4 per mm at margin to ~1 per mm at apex; honeycomb-like, radially elongated; white, some FBs with a distinct orange cast (5A3-5A4); tubes up to 3mm long; hyphal pegs visible in pore mouths.

Stipe: up to 17mm long, up to 5mm thick, tapering below; glabrous, roughly concolorous with hymenium, somewhat darker/dingier below.

Spore Deposit: not specifically recorded, presumed white/light

Odor/Taste: nondescript

Substrate: in grass beneath Salix sp. (?), some on twigs and herbaceous debris

Habitat: landscaped/cultivated area, ~3400m

results.notes:
Pileus: ~2.25-5cm in diam, convex, some warped or contorted from stalks of nearby grass; smooth, glabrous, somewhat viscid when moist; 6E7 to 6D5 to 6C6, lightening to 5A2 in places; margin incurved when young; context cream colored, “saturating” in KOH but not particularly changing.

Lamellae: narrowly attached to deeply sinuate; ~6B3 to 6D/E5 in age; up to 9mm broad; close; lamellulae present in two series; margins edged with white (cheilocystidia?)

Stipe: 2.5-7cm long, 3.5-7mm thick, slightly enlarged above and below; twisted fibrous; upper 1-1.5cm adorned with white cottony to scruffy flecks, white to 6E5/5D4; shiny-pearlescent throughout; context white and “saturating” in KOH but not particularly changing; darkening somewhat in age; texture fibrous, fragile.

Partial Veil: cottony fibrillose to cortinoid with some thicker, slightly darker floccose patches; flaring upward; occasionally leaving an evanescent fibrillose zone near the apex.

Spore Deposit: not recorded, presumed medium brown

Odor/Taste: subtly sweet sweet and raphanoid fragrance, bitter raphanoid taste

Substrate: in grass beneath Populus balsamifera

Habitat: landscaped/cultivated area, ~3400m

Ecoregion: Central Andean Wet Puna (NT1003)

Collector(s): D. Newman

results.notes:
Pileus: 1.3-2.5cm in diam, parabolic to convex, strongly hygrophanous (observed in dry conditions), surface smooth, sparkling under light, 5A2 to 5B3, darkening in age and upon drying; some faintly striate from nearly disc to margin, others less so; context cream colored; all tissues darkening to 8F4 in KOH

Lamellae: broadly attached, 8D2 when young to 7F5 in age, up to 3mm broad, crowded; edges frosted crystalline white (cheilocystidia?); lamellulae present in one series.

Stipe: ~2.5-5cm long, 1-6mm thick, upper 1-2cm striate and covered with a fine, pruinose, white layer; elsewhere with scattered, very fine, wispy brown hairs; very fragile, hollow, enlarged below; base with cottony white tomentum; pearlescent, white to off-white, dingier below; context concolorous, darkening to 8D3 in KOH.

Partial Veil: not observed, though perhaps manifesting in wispy, fibrillose remnants scattered about the fruiting bodies.

Spore Deposit: dark purple-brown

Odor/Taste: mild

Substrate: in grass beneath a big Eucalyptus

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1042/2017_DSC7146

Habitat: mixed broadleaved and conifer wood, locally almost flat terrain, cretaceous clastic rock (flysh) bedrock, in shade; dry place, partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 8-10 deg C, elevation 470 m (1.550 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: still standing Alnus sp. bark lightly overgrown with mosses; on northeast side of the trunk.

Place: Bovec basin, east of Bovec, Rabeljnik hill, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: This incredible small and filigree mushroom is, no doubt, frequently overlooked. Tiny, only a few millimeters tall, more or less brown on more or less brown, cracked tree bark, it hides itself perfectly. However, looked from close the impression is much different. Its size, unusual hyphal ends of the cortical layer of the stipe and hypha with strange digitiform outgrowths distinguish it from other small Mycena species.

Growing in a group of a few fruit bodies, pileus diameter 2 to 4 mm, SP very faint, almost invisible, probably whitish.

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Sony a6000 / Carl Zeiss Vario-Tessar E 16-70mm/ f4
results.location_name: Bovec basin, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia

results.notes: This will be sequenced. My bet is that it will turn out to be either M. brunnea or Mel-8. M. brunnea is described by Kuo et al. 2012 as having a conical cap attached with a sinus, ridges that are dark brown to black in young fruit bodies, a mealy to granulated stem, and “Appearing under hardwoods, including A. menziesii and Quercus spp.; probably also to be expected in non-burned conifer forests.” In fact we did find a specimen of M. brunnea (sequenced) under ponderosa pine in Az. This obs was collected in an area of pine, cypress and oak. Regarding the similarity of M. brunnea and Mel-8 Kuo et al 2012 says: “Among the species that are similar in appearance to M. brunnea, only the poorly known Morchella sp. Mel-8 apparently inhabits similar western habitats.” Mel-8 was found under incense cedar, a member of the cypress family.

results.notes: A small fresh fruiting in weedy grassy area after an overnight rain. This is the third year in a row for this species to appear in this area … slightly early this year, likely due to the warmest February in St. Louis history and an overall very mild winter. Largest cap: 7 cm., woolly, some pink showing under the wet whitish fibers, white partial veil covering those in the button stage; pink (including the button stage), free gills. Stipe: 4 cm. X 1.5 cm., slightly enlarged at base, fragile ring. No distinct odor. KOH negative on cap and flesh. Brown spore print.

results.notes: Resupinate with patches up to 2.3 cm wide on the side of a cut Acer saccharinum log. Margins smooth, whitish and paler than the pores, although the mouths of the pores were paler than the rest of the pores and similar in color to the margins of the fruiting bodies. Fruiting bodies up to 0.2 cm deep. Pores irregular, some divided and irpicoid, ~2-4 per mm. Fruiting bodies soft and pliable. Odor indistinct. Generative hyphae with clamp connections. Did not really investigate the hyphae beyond that and that I did not notice any clear amyloid or dextrinoid reactions. Did not find cystidia. Basidia not segmented. Spores smooth, hyaline, inamyloid and allantoid. Spore measurements: 5.2 [6.1 ; 6.9] 7.8 × 1.7 [1.9 ; 2.1] 2.3 µm, Q = 3 [3.2 ; 3.3] 3.5; N = 10 ; C = 95%, Me = 6.5 × 2 µm; Qe = 3.2
results.location_name: 2920 Bremen St., Columbus, Ohio, USA

results.notes: Fruiting bodies hard and multiperitheciate. Growing scattered through the bark of a conifer log in a woodpile. Ascomata up to 0.4 cm wide and 0.2 cm tall. All structures inamyloid. results.notes: It was fruiting on the inside edge of the bark on a large decayed sugar pine stump. I picked this up thinking it was Byssocorticium because of the blue-green color, but the spores are distinctive of Amarodon. This is only the second collection I’ve seen in California. The first was at collected at Pt. Reyes several years ago. It keys to A. wakefieldiniae based on the spore size 3.9 to 5.4, but this species is known only from the type in Florida and I have not checked the description. For now “sp.” seems safest.

results.notes:
I succeeded to find again the place of observation 237422, with specimens classified as Rinodina fimbriata. Since that time there were some doubts about the chemistry and if it is spreaded at the place.
This time I performed the spot tests, which revealeded the existence of lichen substances: the K test produced a clear yellow color that evolved to some red-brown coloration at the end; this coloration was kept with KC (see the photos attached). Therefore, R. fimbriata has to be ruled out, since it has no lichen substances. However, it should be noted that all the specimens observed have apothecia with a thalline margin concolor with the discs (and not with the thallus, as most of Rinodina spp.); on the other hand, the apothecia are very thin, flat, completely sessile and dark coloured, almost black.
In relation to the former observation, the thalli are lighter coloured; the grey-green seems to be now replaced by cream or light brown.
The habitat consist of a big block of granite and all the specimens were found at the same block (there are more three or four similar blocks at the place). Only two or three specimens have thalli bigger than 2 cm (across).
Let’s see what the microscopy has to tell …

-
-
Biotopes: grows in sandy soil, under hardwood (Fagus), (Betula), (Quercus);
Pileus 8-15 mm Ø, ± conical at first, convex to spreading, slightly depressed, ± nippled, fibrillated and squamous, ± mechuleux towards the center, ± spiky, brown to reddish brown, darker in the center;
Gills indented to sinuate, spaced to sub-spaced, with lamellae and lamellules, broad to subventrous, yellowish cream, with whitish border;
Stipe 13-19 × 1-2 mm Ø, cylindrical, full, with small whitish fibrils at the apex, sub-bulbose, reddish-brown, curving slightly at the base;
Cortine white;
Flesh reddish brown;
Exhalation spermatic;
Flavor spermatic;
Spore print = A collection that did not give much spore print. For a complete microscopic study, see the following micrograph : https://www.flickr.com/...
Macrochemical reaction: P.D.A.B. = 0; gills become weak purple pink (presence of indole)
Remarks : This collection was compared to I. curvipes. Although microscopy is similar, macromorphology does not match.

results.notes:
Used the lincoff Audobon guide and came up with Calvatia rubroflava. However it has been suggested that this might be Bovista colorata due to its size. There is a thread on iNatralist with the details:
https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/5549671

I did some reading and this paper covers both species.
Arizona gasteroid fungi I:Lycoperdaceae (Agaricales, Basidiomycota),Bates, S.T., Roberson, R.W. and Desjardin, D.E
http://www.fungaldiversity.org/fdp/sfdp/FD37-4.pdf
The paper indicates that the size of C. rubroflava can range from 20-60(100)mm.
So I believe that the specimens are in the range. However they also mention colors using the Methuen handbook as a reference. All the colors they mention are what I would call orange. Where as the colors mentioned for B. colorata/aestivalis are what I observe and are yellows, page 4 or earlier.

That said I think some of the pictures I have match Kuo’s C. rubroflava
http://www.mushroomexpert.com/calvatia_rugosa.html
rather than mycoquebec’s B. colorata. http://www.mycoquebec.org/...

B. colorata was reported north of here in Cook Forest State park at a NAMA foray but I don’t know it that was in the conifer/hemlock section or not, we found these specimens on an alluvial island with deciduous trees.

I’m not yet convinced it is B. colorata but I agree it is probably not C. rubroflava. Sorry no voucher for this specimen as I did not realize what I had in my hands.

results.notes:
On a wet, well rotted branch, immersed in mud and water—the standing, dirty water left after recent heavy rainfalls, just across Visitor Center. The branch was hosting a Scutellinia and a Lasiosphaeria species, this phycomycete was found accidentally while examining the “lasio”.

Apparently, this is a conidium of an aquatic fungus, “Ingoldian” is the name for the group of species like this that one typically looks for in water foam. (https://blog.mycology.cornell.edu/...)

The arms measure about 100×10 microns.

results.notes:
I am anxious to identify this mushroom that grows in my yard. Ten days ago one of our labrador retrievers died from ingesting a mushroom. The toxicology report stated the liver damage was due to mushroom poisoning. We believe she got the mushroom on a trip to the foothills (Calaveras County). Last week I had other mushrooms from my yard identified by Plant Pathology at UC Davis as Agrocybe. Now, these show up. We still have one dog and I am paranoid that she will find a poisonous one in our yard. Thank you for any help you can provide as to the toxicity of this mushroom.
I have a photo of the gills but cannot get it to upload.

results.notes:
There was a time when I made several observations of the species Ramalina lacera, many of them posted here at MO. From those observation I knew that it is usually infertile. Therefore, I was very surprised when I saw a huge group of specimens of this species many of them fertile.
Consulting some references, I could read the following:
1) From CNALH, where the description from the Great Sonoran Desert Lichen Flora is reproduced:
“Apothecia: not seen for Mexican specimens”
2) The British Flora says: “Apothecia unknown”.
3) The website “AFL-lichens”
http://www.afl-lichenologie.fr/...
says: “Apothécies : non observées”.
4) The website “Lichens maritimes”
http://www.lichensmaritimes.org/...
says: “Apothecia unknown, nevertheless see pictures below demonstrating that some colonies may have apothecia – to be confirmed” and, in fact, two photos showing fertile specimens (one apothecium each) are displayed.
Therefore it seems that fertile specimens if existing are extremely rare. So, am I wrong in the identification of these specimens as Ramalina lacera?

results.notes: So far the only observations I have made of Rinodina oleae were in this location, at a distance of about 500 meters from the place of this one. The habitat is similar, the interface of the dunes with firm soil, where some shrubs constitute the vegetation (see http://mushroomobserver.org/image/show_image/614306). The specimens of Rinodina grew on the branches of a fallen big shrub. As lichen partners there were Ramalina spp. and many Lecanora, making the identification difficult because some of the Lecanora spp. are very similar to R. oleae. In observation 239739 I took R. oleae for a Lecanora; I hope this time do not be the reverse.

results.notes:
On a spine of intruded siliceous rock in a semi-arid grassland setting.
I haven’t done micro on this one yet but see observation 239956 for a nearby collection that I think is the same species. Whether or not its S. areolata or S. drummondii remains to be determined. Jason Hollinger said the following:
“…this looks more like Staurothele areolata. But that said, very well-developed S. drummondii, especially on sandstone, can have areolata-like areoles in the center. The key is the thallus margin: in S. drummondii the areoles get smaller and becoming thin snaky tatters at the edge; in S. areolata the areoles get a little smaller but remain clearly areolate right to the margin, which is distinct and abrupt.”

I added some close up shots of the margins, which still don’t make it clear to me.

results.notes:
[PNW Key Council Foray. Found by Fred Rhoades.]

Growing on a mossy dead branch, 4 cm thick, in a mixed conifer/alder forest. The largest cap about 1 cm across, stem 2.5 cm. Pale color, gill edges reddish (now showing well in the photos).

Basidia 4-spored, also 2- and 3-spored (observed one floating and turning so am pretty sure it was 3-spored), measuring about 30+6 x 8. Spores 8-10 × 6-7. Cheilocystidia 46-76 10-12. No pleurocystidia. Hyphae of the pileipellis 3-5 microns wide. Clamps present in all tissues.

M. rubromarginata is not a species that we routinely come across and identify, but this seems to be a solid match.
results.location_name: Gordon Bay Provincial Park, Cowichan Lake, Vancouver Island, British Columbia, Canada

results.notes: Smallest caps 2.5 cm, largest 6 cm. Stems medium size relative to caps. Smallest stipe 8 mm width, largest 1.5 cm. Fine delicate scales found on some. Others bald presumably scales wiped away. Found in large gregarious clump growing inside a hole in an Oak tree where I’ve previously found another type of Gymnopilus more than once in fall. Those on bottom having caps coated thoroughly in rusty spores. No ring present, but ring zone found on nearly all. Sweetish smell. Bitter taste. Green staining near ring zone. Definitely active though very weakly so. Orange brown staining nearly matching spore color. All caps of various shapes, misshapen circles rather than perfect circles.

results.notes:
Collected, photographed and described by Francis York of the Kaw Valley Mycological Society.

Thanks for sharing these Jon. and thanks for the feedback.

Macroscopically, about the only thing these LBMs exhibit that prevent them from falling into the category of excruciatingly boring, is that ring—and perhaps the minute and irregular serrations on gill edges of young specimens.

Spore prints were brownish, but I didn’t get any particularly thick deposit. There is a bit of a rusty color to them however… I think.

For a bit more info beyond the photos, in larger specimens the upper portion of the stipe (above the ring) was peeling back with pale raised fibrils, colored as the stems, and of a fairly persistent nature. Mature fruitbodies were quite pallid, with the caps a shade or two darker than the stems. The upper portion of the stipe was also somewhat flattened in many specimens. None were particularly fragile. In terms of their texture, they reminded me of Agrocybe.

Caps were hygrophanous, dryish, not particularly striate, and ranged in size from about 1.5–3 centimeters. KOH on cap surface produced no reaction. Upon drying completely the caps darkened a bit.

Microscopically they were QUITE boring. Spores were in the 7–8 micron range from end-to-end, inamyloid, and featured an oil droplet or two.

Cystidia were nothing to write home about. No remarkable projections possessing interesting shapes. Just cylindrical to clavate cells.

The pileipellus consisted of layer of uniformly inflated cells that were more or less roundish. And again, nothing standing out beyond the surface and CERTAINLY no cool shapes deviating from the norm.

The habitat consisted of cottonwoods, silver maple, box elder, and small elms, roughly in that order.
results.location_name: Kaw River, Douglas Co., Kansas, USA

results.notes:
This is a complement to my posting on 3 – 29, on the same species..
We had a meeting of our mushroom club, SIMA, several people brought this mushroom from different locations, and in different conditions. So is spread around the valley.
I identified them by sight to be the same of my previous finding, which I believe to be Clitocybe brunneocephala. It checks as described on the posting on 3 – 29.
There are two possible objections to this identification:
The range was considered till now much smaller, mainly Ca. However Boise is much lower that an observation here in Carson City, NV.
The spore, while it checks in size, appears smooth. But I see several observations also here that describe them as smooth. Is it possible that the spores of C. brunneocephala are in fact smooth? Have anybody check them and found them to be rough?

results.notes:
I am not sure what to make of this critter. I’ve been watching white aethelia emerge and mature on a certain hardwood log for several weeks (several years on the ground). Compared with the “standard” bright-yellow-plasmodium-turning-salmon Fuligo septica that is common and consistent throughout my oak-hickory woods, this one looks quite different.

“White Fuligo”: plasmodium white; aethelial surface initially smooth and white, soon turning pink, then brown; spore mass brown with little lime; spores 7 microns and spiny.

“Standard” Fuligo septica: plasmodium yellow; aethelial surface initially lumpy yellow, turning salmon; spore mass black with lots of lime; spores 7 microns and smooth.

The Stephenson and Stempen Handbook of Slime Molds says that F. septica can be many colors (a point also made by Jan Thornhill in a recent blog post) with spores “nearly smooth to minutely spinluose,” and is distinguished from other Fuligos by spores less than 10 microns.
So by that measure, my “white Fuligos” should be F. septica. But they look so different! Thoughts?
results.location_name: Tallassee Highlands, Clarke Co., Georgia, USA
